title: Computer Code
text:
Learning Outcomes
After completing this supplemental lesson you should…

Understand that the execution speed and size of computer code presented in SCoRE could often be improved because it is written to be easy to understand.
Appreciate the difference between global constants and global variables as implemented in SCoRE code.
Be able to use global variables to make quantities available to a function when they cannot be passed to it as arguments.
Understand the code structure used in SCoRE and realize that you can structure your code differently if you wish.

title: Computer Code
text:
Preparation

Read Reaction Engineering Basics, Chapter 8.

title: Computer Code
text:
Computer Code Lesson

 Coding Conventions and Structure (YouTube)

title: Preparing to Start SCoRE
text:
Prerequisite Knowledge
SCoRE is very similar to the introductory reaction engineering courses found in the undergraduate curricula of chemical engineering departments in the United States. In those curricula, the reaction engineering course is typically taken by students in their third or fourth year. They are typically expected to posess prerequisite knowledge from courses taken earlier in their curriculum. SCoRE assumes that its learners have similar prerequisite knowledge as described in the following video.
 Prerequisite Knowledge Video (forthcoming on YouTube)

title: Preparing to Start SCoRE
text:
Computer Setup
In SCoRE you will need to use computer software to solve different kinds of equations numerically. SCoRE shows how to do this using either Python or Matlab. You can use whatever software you choose, but unless you are quite knowledgeable about numerical methods, it is recommended that you set up either Python or Matlab.

Setting up Python for Use in SCoRE

 Setting up Python Video (forthcoming on YouTube)
 score_utils.py



Setting up Matlab for Use in SCoRE

 Setting up Matlab Video (forthcoming on YouTube)
 solve_ivodes.m
 fit_to_SR_data.m


This website is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-Non-Commercial-NoDerivatives 4.0 International License (CC BY-NC-ND 4.0).

title: SCoRE
text:
Make sure there is a PFR kinetics assignment that uses the volume as the dependent variable.
Compare linear least squares, non-linear least squares using absolute errors, and non-linear least squares using relative errors.

title: Using SCoRE
text:
Navigating the SCoRE Site
Three menus appear on every page of the SCoRE website. The menu at the top of the page contains links to other web sites. One of those links is for the free, online book that SCoRE is based on, “Reaction Engineering Basics.
The menu on the left side of each page serves as the Table of Contents. Items with the symbol, \(\gt\), following them will reveal a sub-menu if you click on them. When you first navigate to a SCo[RE] page, the sub-menu that contains it will be open (i. e. followed by the symbol, \(\lor\)) and all the other sub-menus will be closed. Items that are not followed by a symbol are links to a single page.
Finally, the menu on the right side of each page provides links to the sub-sections of the page you are viewing.

title: Using SCoRE
text:
Suggested Learning Strategy
SCoRE is a self-study version of an in-person course. The in-person course is taught as a so-called “flipped” class. Unfortunately, complete replication of the in-person course isn’t possible, necessitating some adaptation. The following video suggests a learning strategy for using SCoRE, suggesting adaptations for aspects of the in-person course that can not be replicated.

 Suggested Learning Strategy Video (forthcoming on YouTube)

title: Using SCoRE
text:
Acronyms and Notation
Several acronyms are used throughout both SCoRE and “Reaction Engineering Basics.” They are summarized in Appendix B of “Reaction Engineering Basics” and in the video below. That appendix and the video below also describe some of the notation used when writing equations. Apologies if some of the notation is used in a non-conventional manner.

 Acronyms and Notation Video (forthcoming on YouTube)

title: Welcome!
text:
SCoRE Site Status
Eventually this sub-section will be replaced with a link to a welcome video. For now, however, I will be using it to log content as it is added to the site.

7/25

Added Computational Supplements Section and placeholder pages for all classes

title: Welcome!
text:
SCoRE Learning Outcomes
Upon successful completion of this course, students will possess the component knowledge and skills necessary for reaction engineering analysis and be able to use them to

Postulate an empirical, mechanistic or theoretical rate expression for a given reaction.
Using kinetics data from an ideal reactor, estimate values for rate expression parameters, assess the accuracy of the rate expression, and evaluate its suitability.
Formulate steady-state and/or transient models of ideal batch, semi-batch, and continuous flow stirred tank reactors and plug flow reactors, use them to predict the response of, optimize, or design a reactor, and qualitatively rationalize or explain the results on a physical/chemical basis.
Formulate steady-state models of simple CSTR and/or PFR systems that may include multiple reactors, stream splits, stream mixing and heat exchangers, use them to predict the response of, optimize or design a system of that type, and qualitatively rationalize or explain the results on a physical/chemical basis.
Formulate steady-state zoned reactor models, segregated-flow reactor models (including, when necessary, numerical approximation of the age function using experimental stimulus/response data) and steady-state axial dispersion reactor models and use them to predict reactor response.


This website is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-Non-Commercial-NoDerivatives 4.0 International License (CC BY-NC-ND 4.0).

title: Solving BVODEs
text:
Learning Outcomes
After completing this supplemental lesson you should…

Know what input must be provided to a BVODE solver.
Know what a derivatives function is, the input it requires and what it returns.
Know what a boundary conditions residuals function is, the input it requires and what it returns. 4 Be able to write specifications for the functions that are needed for solving BVODEs.
Be able to solve a set of BVODEs using Python or Matlab.

title: Solving BVODEs
text:
Preparation

title: Class 1
text:
Reaction Engineering, Ethics, and Safety
Class 1 defines reaction engineering. Codes of engineering ethics are presented and the importance of safety in chemical processing is stressed.
crumbs: Class 1: Reaction Engineering, Ethics, and Safety

title: Class 1
text:
Learning Outcomes
After completing Class 1 you should…

have some understanding of what reaction engineering is
be aware of the AIChE code of ethics and your responsibility to adhere to it
know that failure to operate chemical processes ethically and safely can lead to death or injury
have identified ways you can act ethically and address safety in your current situation
crumbs: Class 1: Reaction Engineering, Ethics, and Safety

title: Class 1
text:
Preparation Assignment

Watch  Class 1 Preparation Video (forthcoming on YouTube)

title: Estimating Parameters
text:
Learning Outcomes
After completing this supplemental lesson you should…

Know what input must be provided to a fitting function and what it returns.
Know what a predicted responses function is, the input it requires, and what it returns.
Be able to write specifications for functions that are needed for estimating parameters.
Be able to estimate parameters using Python or Matlab.

title: Estimating Parameters
text:
Preparation

Read Reaction Engineering Basics, Appendix F.6.

title: Estimating Parameters
text:
Equations and Solvers Lesson

 Estimating Parameters (YouTube)
 Using Python to Estimate Parameters (YouTube)

 score_utils.py
 using_Python_to_estimate_parameters.py

 Using Matlab to Estimate Parameters (YouTube)

 fit_to_SR_data.m
 using_Matlab_to_estimate_parameters.m



This website is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-Non-Commercial-NoDerivatives 4.0 International License (CC BY-NC-ND 4.0).

title: Equations and Solvers
text:
Learning Outcomes
After completing this supplemental lesson you should…

Be able to describe the categories of quantities that appear in equations.
Be able to identify a set of equations as either ATEs, IVODEs, BVODEs, or DAEs.
Be able to rewrite an ATE as an equivalent residual expression.
Be able to rewrite a set of ODEs as an equivalent set of derivative expressions.
Understand that the software being used places constraints on functions you must write to solve equations numerically.

title: Equations and Solvers
text:
Preparation

Read Reaction Engineering Basics, Appendices F.1 through F.4.

title: Equations and Solvers
text:
Equations and Solvers Lesson

 Quantities Appearing in Equations (YouTube)
 Equation Types (YouTube)
 Important Equation Formats (YouTube)
 Equations Solvers (YouTube)
